awd_titl_txt: Dark Matter and Rare-Event Searches with XENON1T/XENONnT
awd_abstract_narration:
What is the nature of Dark Matter? This is one of the most intriguing open questions of modern science and answering it is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and particle physics. Over the last three decades, to solve this puzzle, physicists all around the world have been building specialized low-background instruments capable of detecting the potential interactions of Dark Matter (DM) particles with ordinary matter. While these searches constrained the features of DM and its coupling rate with regular matter, the question remains unanswered. This award supports the University of Chicago group to continue its involvement in the XENON program, a direct search for DM. The XENON1T detector has been operating at the Gran Sasso National Laboratory in central Italy since Spring 2016. It features a 2-tonne Liquid Xenon (LXe) target, instrumented as a two-phase Time Projection Chamber (TPC), capable of detecting possible interactions of DM particles with ordinary matter. XENON1T/nT will probe the Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) paradigm, either detecting them or further constraining their features, as well as a variety of other DM candidates. In parallel, this program aims to further develop noble-liquids TPC technology, broadly used in particle physics for dark matter and neutrino searches.

This award will support the continuation of a partnerships with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Chicago (a local minority-dominated public school), the Great Lakes Planetarium Association and the Space Explorer Program. The program uses the mystery of dark matter to engage students, educators, and the broader public in cutting edge science. It recognizes that high school teachers are the experts in communication and dissemination and best qualified to find creative ways to integrate the PI's research into their teaching. The program targets teachers and planetarium staff and will have a deep and broad impact on hundreds of Under Represented Minority (URM) students, and thousands of Planetarium visitors. A part of the program will plug into the Space Explorer Program, a summer camp for high school URM students interested in astronomy and science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award allowed the University of Chicago (UChicago) group to contribute to the XENON program, a direct search for dark matter. While the existence of dark matter is extensively proved by its gravitational effect on galactic, cluster of galaxies and cosmic scales, its nature at the moment is still unknown although it is thought to be constituted by a new species of elementary particle interacting very rarely with ordinary matter. The XENON program, operated at Laboratori National del Gran Sasso in Italy, features a family of liquid-xenon-based detectors, of increasing size and decreasing background, designed to detect the potential rare scatterings of dark matter particles within xenon atoms. The support from this award, in particular, allowed the UChicago group to play a leading role in the analysis of data from XENON1T as well as in the construction and early commissioning of its successor, XENONnT. XENON1T, featuring a 2-tonne liquid xenon active target, was operated from early 2016 to the end of 2018 and the analysis of its data is still ongoing. XENONnT, about 3 times larger than its predecessor, was commissioned in 2021 and is operative since then. 

 

Both experiments, specially designed and constructed to minimize the background rate and mitigate known sources of undesired interactions, reached ultra low background levels with XENONnT featuring the lowest background rate ever achieved in any dark matter detector. While to date no discovery was reported, during the award period both XENON1T and XENONnT data were used to set stringent constraints, world-leading at the moment of their publication, on several extensions of the Particle Standard Model, limiting the potential explanations for the dark matter puzzle and further improving our knowledge about what dark matter might or might not be. The UChicago group, with the support from this award, was particularly active in the study of extremely light dark matter expected to produce tiny ionization signals down to a single electron, as well as in the search for anomalies in the electron recoil spectrum detected in the core of the XENON1T detector. The extraordinary low background conditions in XENON1T and XENONnT is enabling a very rich and diversified science outcome, extending its reach well beyond dark matter and spanning from solar neutrinos coherent scattering on nuclei to neutrinoless double beta decay of the Xe-136 isotope, from neutrino anomalous magnetic moment to the first measurements of double electron capture on Xe-124, the longest lifetime decay predicted by the Standard Model ever observed .

 

Beyond the extensive science outcomes, the XENON program allowed for engaging the next generation of scientists. In particular the present award allowed to expose two undergraduate students, two graduate students and one postdoctoral scholar to cutting edge science, making them familiar with the scientific method and training them in the use of advanced techniques in experimental physics, statistics, coding and engineering. The development of liquid xenon technology in the context of the XENON program allowed also to further inform its application in medical imaging and nuclear safeguards purposes.
